_exec_summary.SummaryText:
RMP EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

The purpose of the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Risk Management Plan (RMP) is to provide guidelines for facilities in California to conduct business in an environmentally safe manner.  The legal authority for the CalARP Program is the California Health and Safety Code, Division 20, Chapter 6.95, Article 2 (commencing with Section 25531).  The California Office of Emergency Services has issued implementation regulations under the California Code of Regulations (CCR) Title 19, Division 2, Chapter 4.5.  The Pacific Gas and Electric Company (PG&E) Small-Scale Natural Gas Liquefaction facility (?LNG Facility?) is subject to RMP requirements because the maximum intended inventory of liquefied natural gas (LNG) exceeds the 10,000-pound federal threshold for methane (this threshold quantity is specified in Table 2 of 19 CCR 2770.5).  This threshold quantity is applicable because natural gas is composed of 90 to 100 percent methane.  

Facility

The LNG Facility is located at 2001 Front Street, Sacramento, California.  The facility produces LNG for fueling vehicles.  The portions of the system subject to CalARP regulations are the LNG storage tank, associated piping and equipment, and the operations for transferring LNG from the storage tank to tanker trucks. 

The primary LNG Facility activities are the storage and transfer of LNG to transport trucks.  LNG production and storage are completely automatic, but the transfer of LNG from the storage tank to a tanker truck is conducted by contractors hired to transport the LNG to its final destination.

Chemical Inventories

As LNG is produced at the LNG Facility, it is collected in a storage tank.  The storage tank capacity is 15,000 gallons; however, due to administrative controls, the maximum volume contained within the tank at any one time is 13,500 gallons, or 47,770 pounds (lbs).  This amount exceeds the federal RMP applicability threshold of 10,000 lbs.  The PG&E LNG Facility is

rogram that complies with the requirements of the CalARP RMP as described in 19 CCR 2765.2.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety

PG&E is committed to providing a safe place of business for the employees and surrounding community.  This RMP document summarizes the programs and procedures in place at the LNG Facility to prevent or minimize the consequences of catastrophic releases of flammable or explosive chemicals.  The RMP provisions are intended to minimize the probability and/or consequences of accidental releases of highly hazardous chemicals from the facility and include such measures as a system hazard review, operation and maintenance procedures, training, compliance auditing, implementation of a management system, and providing routine updates.

PG&E will address and resolve all of the action items identified in the Process Hazard Analyses for each RMP-covered process.  In the future, to ensure that the appropriate changes occur as necessary to maintain and improve safety, ongoing Process Hazard Reviews, Process Hazard Analyses, Training, Compliance Audits, inspection and maintenance, Contractor programs, Hot Work Permit issuance, and Incident Investigations will be conducted as required by the RMP.  Program 3 changes will be managed under the Management of Change system.  Updates to the RMP will be completed as necessary in response to these activities.
